title: CHAPTER 7 BANKRUPTCY - STATEMENT OF INTENTION
question: WHEN SOMEONE FILES A BANKRUPTCY CHAPTER 7 AND THE STATEMENT OF INTENTION REGARDING REAL PROPERTY AND SECURED DEBT AGAINST IT....SAYS THEY "INTEND" ON REAFFIRMING THE DEBT......MUST THEY THEN FILE A REAFFIRMATION OF DEBT TO FOLLOW THRU WITH THAT INTENTION OR IS THE DEBT RETAINED WITHOUT THE FILING
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Reaffirmation of debt and bankruptcy,Debt,Lien,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Foreclosure,Car loan,Mortgage debt
answers: You should probably not being reaffirming debt on a mortgage. The creditor is usually the one that prepares and sends you the reaffirmation agreement. Reaffirmation agreements are usually done with car loans not real property loans. The Statement of Intention is what is "intended" and it does not necessarily lock the debtor into doing anything. It is a plan of what the debtor intends to do so the creditor is aware. Without the debtor entering into a reaffirmation agreement the debtor's personally liability is discharged. You should be aware of the consequences of reaffirming debt. I recommend you speak with a bankruptcy attorney.

The Statement of Intention lets the creditors know what your intentions are. I do not suggest signing a reaffirmation agreement on real property, in fact one of the answer choices on the statement of intention form is that you will keep the property and pay pursuant to contract. This is the answer my clients use when it comes to real property. When you reaffirm a debt you loose the ability to discharge the debt because it becomes a post petition debt.
The reason that it is usually not wise to reaffirm a real property debt is in case something happens after your discharge and you are unable to keep the property, the secured debt will be considered a pre-petition debt and your discharge will apply to the debt so the lender will not come after you for the difference between what the property sells at foreclosure and the amount of the loan (a deficiency). For a secured debt that was used to purchase or improve the property the California 1 Action Rule prevents the secured creditor from claiming a deficiency after foreclosing, however, if the secured debt was used to pay off credit cards or something else, these lenders will claim a deficiency and then you will have lost the property and face a deficiency judgment.
The only debt that you should reaffirm, if you are keeping the property, is an automobile loan. Here's why, the automobile industry paid their lobbyists and the lawmakers agreed to carve out an exception to the Bankruptcy Code that requires a person to enter into a reaffirmation agreement if they intend to keep their vehicle. If the agreement is not entered on the court docket before discharge then the lender has the right to repossess the vehicle after discharge, even if the vehicle is properly insured and all payments on the loan are current. The only exception is if the Court will not approve the reaffirmation agreement, then as long as the payments are current and the vehicle is properly insured the lender is stopped from repossession.
You do not have to reaffirm on the mortgage note. The lien on the house will survive and so long as payments are being made, the mortgage company cannot foreclose.

No. Debtor not obligated to actually reaffirm debt they state they intend to reaffirm. Statement of intent not an emforceable obligation to reaffirm.
Caution. Carefully consider risks which come with reaffirming debt secured by real property.
review with BK counsel before reaffirming the debt.

Never reaffirm a mortgage debt in California because that would arguably create personal liability to the Borrower and negate the advantages of the California Anti-deficiency statute. I don't think that this issue has been litigated in California, but why take a chance.
They don't need to follow through with their intention but if it's to be reaffirmed, a reaffirmation agreement has to be filed.

As stated by my colleagues, it is rarely advisable to reaffirm a mortgage debt. If you don't have a lawyer representing you, the mortgage company is supposed to prepare a reaffirmation agreement and send it to you. The reason many don't is because they know the bankruptcy judges rarely approve them. Personally, i have never recommended any of my clients reaffirm a mortgage debt since I began practicing law in 1976.

The statement if intent is simply that...a statement of intention. it is generally the duty of the creditor to send a reaffirmation proposal to the debtor. However, most bankruptcy judges won't allow reaffirmation of debts secured by real property without very very good reasons.

If there is no reaffirmation agreement on file, the debt is discharged. However, the lien will remain in place unles removed by a court order or by agreement. if you are referring to a home loan, for example, most debtors will simply keep the house and continue paying the mortgage.
